title: Tokyo Complete Travel Guide - Japan's Dynamic Capital
content:
Tokyo, Japan's bustling capital, is a captivating blend of ultramodern and traditional elements. Home to over 13 million people, this megacity offers endless discoveries for every type of traveler.

## Overview
Tokyo is one of the world's most vibrant cities, seamlessly combining cutting-edge technology with rich cultural heritage. From neon-lit skyscrapers to peaceful temples, Tokyo provides an unforgettable urban experience.

## Top Districts & Attractions

### Shibuya
- **Famous for**: World's busiest pedestrian crossing
- **Highlights**: Shibuya Sky observation deck, Hachiko statue
- **Best time**: Evening for the full neon experience

### Harajuku
- **Famous for**: Youth culture and unique fashion
- **Highlights**: Takeshita Street, Meiji Shrine
- **Best time**: Weekends for street fashion spotting

### Asakusa
- **Famous for**: Traditional Tokyo atmosphere
- **Highlights**: Senso-ji Temple, Nakamise Shopping Street
- **Best time**: Early morning to avoid crowds

### Ginza
- **Famous for**: Luxury shopping and dining
- **Highlights**: High-end boutiques, traditional restaurants
- **Best time**: Sunday afternoons (pedestrian zone)

### Shinjuku
- **Famous for**: Entertainment and business hub
- **Highlights**: Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building, Golden Gai
- **Best time**: Evening for nightlife

## Iconic Landmarks

### Tokyo Tower
- **Height**: 333 meters
- **Observation decks**: Main (150m) and Top (250m)
- **Hours**: 9:00 AM - 11:00 PM
- **Price**: Adults ¥3,000 (Top Deck)

### Tokyo Skytree
- **Height**: 634 meters (world's second-tallest structure)
- **Observation decks**: Tembo Deck (350m), Tembo Galleria (450m)
- **Hours**: 8:00 AM - 10:00 PM
- **Price**: Adults ¥2,100-3,400

### Meiji Shrine
- **Dedicated to**: Emperor Meiji and Empress Shoken
- **Features**: 70-hectare forested area in central Tokyo
- **Hours**: Sunrise to sunset (free admission)
- **Special**: Traditional Shinto weddings on weekends

## Best Time to Visit

### Spring (March - May)
- **Weather**: Mild temperatures (15-25°C)
- **Highlights**: Cherry blossom season (sakura)
- **Crowds**: Very busy, especially during Golden Week
- **Recommendation**: Book accommodations early

### Summer (June - August)
- **Weather**: Hot and humid (25-35°C)
- **Highlights**: Summer festivals (matsuri)
- **Considerations**: Rainy season in June-July

### Autumn (September - November)
- **Weather**: Comfortable temperatures (15-25°C)
- **Highlights**: Beautiful fall foliage
- **Advantages**: Clear skies, less rain

### Winter (December - February)
- **Weather**: Cold but dry (5-15°C)
- **Advantages**: Fewer crowds, clear views of Mt. Fuji
- **Special**: New Year celebrations

## Transportation

### JR Pass (Japan Rail Pass)
- **Tourist exclusive**: Only for foreign visitors
- **Coverage**: All JR trains including some Shinkansen
- **Duration**: 7, 14, or 21 days
- **Price**: ¥29,650 for 7 days
- **Recommendation**: Must-have for multi-city travel

### Tokyo Metro & Subway
- **Coverage**: Extensive network covering entire metropolitan area
- **IC Cards**: Suica or Pasmo for convenient travel
- **Daily passes**: ¥800 for unlimited Tokyo Metro rides
- **Tips**: Download Google Translate app for station names

### Taxi
- **Availability**: Abundant but expensive
- **Starting fare**: ¥420 for first 1.1km
- **Payment**: Cash preferred, some accept IC cards
- **Language**: Limited English, have destination written in Japanese

## Budget Guide

### Budget Travel ($50-80/day)
- **Accommodation**: Hostels, capsule hotels (¥2,000-4,000/night)
- **Food**: Convenience stores, ramen shops (¥500-1,000/meal)
- **Transportation**: Walking + basic public transport
- **Activities**: Free temples, parks, window shopping

### Mid-range Travel ($100-150/day)
- **Accommodation**: Business hotels (¥8,000-12,000/night)
- **Food**: Mid-range restaurants (¥1,500-3,000/meal)
- **Transportation**: Unlimited metro passes
- **Activities**: Paid attractions, some shopping

### Luxury Travel ($200+/day)
- **Accommodation**: High-end hotels (¥20,000+/night)
- **Food**: Fine dining, kaiseki restaurants (¥5,000+/meal)
- **Transportation**: Private cars, premium experiences
- **Activities**: Exclusive tours, luxury shopping

## Cultural Etiquette

### Public Behavior
- **Bowing**: Slight bow when greeting or thanking
- **Noise levels**: Keep conversations quiet on public transport
- **Eating**: Don't eat or drink while walking
- **Phone calls**: Avoid on trains and buses

### Temple/Shrine Etiquette
- **Purification**: Wash hands and rinse mouth at entrance
- **Prayer**: Bow twice, clap twice, bow once
- **Photography**: Check for restrictions, especially indoors
- **Clothing**: Dress modestly, remove hats

### Dining Etiquette
- **Chopsticks**: Don't stick them upright in rice
- **Slurping**: Acceptable and encouraged for noodles
- **Tipping**: Not customary, can be offensive
- **Sharing**: Order individual dishes rather than sharing

## Food & Dining

### Must-Try Foods
- **Sushi**: Fresh fish at Tsukiji Outer Market
- **Ramen**: Different styles in various districts
- **Tempura**: Light, crispy battered seafood and vegetables
- **Yakiniku**: Japanese-style grilled meat
- **Wagyu**: Premium Japanese beef

### Dining Districts
- **Tsukiji**: Fresh seafood market and restaurants
- **Shinjuku**: Golden Gai for drinks, Omoide Yokocho for yakitori
- **Shibuya**: International cuisine and trendy spots
- **Ginza**: High-end traditional restaurants

## Shopping

### Electronics
- **Akihabara**: Electronics district, anime culture
- **Yodobashi Camera**: Large electronics stores
- **Tax-free**: Available for tourists with passport

### Fashion
- **Harajuku**: Youth fashion, cosplay items
- **Omotesando**: High-end international brands
- **Shibuya**: Department stores like Shibuya 109

### Traditional Items
- **Asakusa**: Traditional crafts, souvenirs
- **Tokyo Station**: Character goods, regional specialties
- **Department store basement**: High-quality food items

## Emergency Information

### Important Numbers
- **Emergency (Fire/Ambulance)**: 119
- **Police**: 110
- **Tourist Hotline**: 050-3816-2787 (24/7, English support)

### Medical
- **International hospitals**: St. Luke's, Tokyo Medical College
- **Pharmacies**: Look for green cross signs
- **Insurance**: Travel insurance highly recommended

### Useful Apps
- **Google Translate**: Camera feature for signs
- **Hyperdia**: Train route planning
- **Tabelog**: Restaurant reviews and ratings
- **Safety Tips**: Official government disaster app

## Weather by Season
- **Spring**: 15-25°C, occasional rain, cherry blossoms
- **Summer**: 25-35°C, high humidity, typhoon season
- **Autumn**: 15-25°C, clear skies, comfortable temperatures
- **Winter**: 5-15°C, dry, occasional snow
